FlashFX Tools

Send comments on this topic.
FlashFX Tera comes with a number of tools which are designed to help you get the most out of the product.

Depending on the type of operating system implementation you are using, these tools are designed so they can be used in several different forms:

  • For those non-monolithic operating systems which support interactively running standalone programs, the FlashFX Tera build process will generate separate executables for each tool, which when executed will interface with the FlashFX Tera device driver. Command-line options are available to customize the tool execution. Windows CE is a typical operating system where the tools exist as separate programs.
  • For those monolithic operating systems which don't support standalone programs, these tools can be linked directly into the device driver by setting FFXCONF_DRIVERAUTOTEST to TRUE in the ffxconf.h file. The tools are run each time the device driver initializes. Command-line options can be specified by editing the settings in ffxconf.h. Nucleus and ThreadX are typical operating systems where you can link the functionality directly into the device driver.
  • For those monolithic operating systems which don't support standalone programs, but can interactively execute commands, these tools can be linked directly into the device driver if desired, and the necessary logic added to interactively invoke them. VxWorks is a good example of an operating system where you can interactively execute functionality that is linked directly into the driver.
  • In environments where user input is supported, such as via terminal emulation, the FlashFX Shell can be used which includes all the FlashFX and DCL based tools.
When moving between different operating systems or different methods of invoking a tool, in most cases the available command-line options are identical, however the command names may vary, and the method by which Disks are specified may be different. All the tools support the "/?" option which will display the syntax and available options.

Note -- Some of these tools are specific to certain operating systems and may not be available in every environment.

FXFMT, Format a FlashFX Tera Disk

A number of low-level data structures are required for the flash array to be used as a disk and must exist prior to using it as such. After the initial format, standard operating system tools can be used to access the disk just as any other disk.

When formatting a flash disk, some amount of space is allocated to the low-level format to keep track of allocations within the flash array. This low-level information is not available to the operating system, so the total flash array available to the operating system is slightly reduced in size.

FXINFO, Report Flash Disk Information

FXINFO reports detailed information regarding the FlashFX Tera device driver, as well as Device and Disk information. FXINFO also reports flash array usage information.

FXIMAGE, Read and Write Flash Images

FXIMAGE is used to read and write flash images. It support a variety of modes, including low-level raw access, VBF-style images, or file-system level images.

FXRECLM, Recover Discarded Flash Space

When data in a flash array is to be rewritten, it is written to a new location within the flash array. As the data is rewritten into a new location in the flash array, the old data becomes invalid. Before long, the flash array contains an excess of invalid data areas and requires a compaction to reclaim these invalid areas for use by new write operations.

FXRECLM recovers discarded space in the flash array by forcing a compaction. Normally, compactions occur on an as-needed basis during write operations. The overhead required to calculate compaction requirements may consume as much as 60 percent of the write time as the number of invalid zones grows.

FXRECLM allows some control over compactions to increase overall performance. In some systems, FXRECLM can be run as a low-priority background task to keep the flash array performance higher than normal.

FXSHELL, FlashFX Command Shell

The FlashFX Shell provides an interactive command-line interface which can be used to invoke all the FlashFX tests and tools, as well as DCL specific tests and tools. For operating systems, additional functionality is supported as well.

FXCHK, Check Flash Disk Spare Units

FXCHK checks all flash disk space units and reports/displays the status of each unit. Each spare unit is stress tested using the selected bit patterns to determine if the unit is good or bad. FXCHK displays complete information on the testing. The physical address and status of each spare unit tested, as well as a summary of related information, are provided.
